results.headline: Picking Up Extra Credit, and Teacher, After School

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daydream Nation

results.summary_short: “Daydream Nation” is Mike Goldbach’s directorial debut, but the film belongs to its protagonist, Kat Dennings, who portrays a precocious teenager with a snide edge of defiance.

results.headline: Have Golden Locks, Seeking Hammer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thor

results.summary_short: “Thor,” directed by Kenneth Branagh, is a programmed triumph of commercial calculation over imagination.

results.headline: A Guess-the-Flavoring Game, and Then Along Comes a War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of There Be Dragons

results.summary_short: “There Be Dragons,” Roland Joffé’s new film, is the story of a lifelong rivalry as well as a Spanish Civil War saga.

results.headline: Fandom Far, Far Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The People vs. George Lucas

results.summary_short: “The People vs. George Lucas” takes a standard interviews-and-clips approach to the history of “Star Wars” fandom, framed by several large and fuzzy issues.

results.headline: Struggles in Colombia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Colors of the Mountain

results.summary_short: In the Andean region of Colombia, people are menaced on one side by guerrillas and on the other by paramilitary groups.

results.headline: Leave It to the Beaver to Do All the Talking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beaver

results.summary_short: A depressed toy manufacturer fails to commit suicide and begins communicating through a hand puppet. Nasty and brutish, the beaver owns the film.

results.headline: Soul Food, Vegan Style

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forks Over Knives

results.summary_short: Lee Fulkerson makes a pedantic yet persuasive case for banishing meat and dairy from the dinner table.

results.headline: New Lovers and the Old Triangle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Something Borrowed

results.summary_short: “Something Borrowed” is a comedy of marriage and a love triangle made up of Ginnifer Goodwin, Kate Hudson and Colin Egglesfield.

results.headline: A Day in the Life of a Prodigal Son

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vito Bonafacci

results.summary_short: In “Vito Bonafacci,” a lapsed Roman Catholic explores religion.

results.headline: Blow the Trumpet, Palooka, Life Is but a Carny Dream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passion Play

results.summary_short: A noir-flavored reverie directed by Mitch Glazer and starring Mickey Rourke and Bill Murray, “Passion Play” is metaphysically ambitious but barely palatable.

results.headline: Tempting Moments

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Night

results.summary_short: A marriage hovers on the brink of temptation in “Last Night.”

results.headline: 2 Families Put Asunder Just Before the ‘I Dos’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jumping the Broom

results.summary_short: In “Jumping the Broom” a nuptial weekend is the backdrop for a trousseau full of revelations revolving around class conflict between the two bridal families.

results.headline: A Man, a Plan and a Gun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hobo With a Shotgun

results.summary_short: In “Hobo,” a homeless Canadian vigilante dreams of landscaping.

results.headline: Crazy for Thimbles
results.display_title: Under the Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story

results.summary_short: In a documentary, Kevin Tostado follows people obsessed with the board game Monopoly.

results.headline: After the War, a Tense Rehabilitation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Caterpillar

results.summary_short: A woman faces her husband, just returned from the Sino-Japanese wars limbless and deaf.

results.headline: Strength in Numbers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Invisible Sign

results.summary_short: “An Invisible Sign” is an excruciatingly whimsical collision of adult themes and kid-friendly aesthetic.

results.headline: H Plus X Plus Z, Formula for 3 Intersecting Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extraordinary Stories

results.summary_short: “Extraordinary Stories,” by the Argentine director Mariano Llinás, is a contagiously playful and thrillingly inventive work.

results.headline: Herzog Finds His Inner Cave Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cave of Forgotten Dreams

results.summary_short: From Werner Herzog, an inside 3-D look at the astonishing Cave of Chauvet-Pont-d’Arc.

results.headline: Swords Drip Red With Revenge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 13 Assassins

results.summary_short: “13 Assassins” is Takashi Miike’s remake of that 1963 samurai tale of love, revenge and liberation.

results.headline: When Past and Present Collide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Go Way Back

results.summary_short: “We Go Way Back,” an early film by the director Lynn Shelton, maps the territory between young dreams and young-adult reality.
